children.value: Today, we’re happy to release React v0.13!
The most notable new feature is
, which allows developers to have more flexibility when writing components. Our eventual goal is for ES6 classes to replace
completely, but until we have a replacement for current mixin use cases and support for class property initializers in the language, we don’t plan to deprecate

At EmberConf and ng-conf last week, we were excited to see that Ember and Angular have been working on speed improvements and now both have performance comparable to React. We’ve always thought that performance isn’t the most important reason to choose React, but we’re still planning more optimizations to

Our planned optimizations require that ReactElement objects are immutable, which has always been a best practice when writing idiomatic React code. In this release, we’ve added runtime warnings that fire when props are changed or added between the time an element is created and when it’s rendered. When migrating your code, you may want to use new
automatically). For more information about our planned optimizations, see GitHub issues
The release is now available for download:

Deprecated patterns that warned in 0.12 no longer work: most prominently, calling component classes without using JSX or React.createElement and using non-component functions with JSX or createElement
after an element is created is deprecated and will cause warnings in development mode; future versions of React will incorporate performance optimizations assuming that props aren’t mutated
) are no longer autobound to the component class
resolution order has changed slightly such that a ref to a component is available immediately after its
method is called; this change should be observable only if your component calls a parent component’s callback within your
, which is an anti-pattern and should be avoided regardless
in life-cycle methods are now always batched and therefore asynchronous. Previously the first call on the first mount was synchronous.
on an unmounted component now warns instead of throwing. That avoids a possible race condition with Promises.
Access to most internal properties has been completely removed, including
Support for using ES6 classes to build React components; see the
, which should be used in place of
. The base class for ES6-based components will not have
. This change will enable some more patterns moving forward.

can now take a function as the first argument for transactional state updates, such as
– this means that you no longer need to use
Support for iterators and immutable-js sequences as children.
Some methods that are available on
-based components are removed or deprecated from ES6 classes (
for adding keys to entire sets of children.
is now deprecated. This functionality can be replaced with several freely available modules.
methods are no longer enumerable by default, which requires
; if you support browsers such as IE8, you can pass
option is available on the jsx command, allowing users to specify and ECMAScript version to target.
restores the previous default behavior. An additional transform is added here to ensure the use of reserved words as properties is safe (eg
The transform for the call spread operator has also been enabled.
A change was made to how some JSX was parsed, specifically around the use of
when inside an element. Previously it would be treated as a string but now it will be treated as a parse error. The
package on npm can be used to find and fix potential issues in your JSX code.
